nodes.text: Intergenerational income mobility varies substantially across places in the United States and geography helps determine children's chances of upward mobility

Method: Construct population measures of parent and child family income and geographic assignment using deidentified federal tax records for >40 million children and their parents (1996–2012); primary sample: 1980–1982 birth cohorts; children assigned to commuting zone where claimed at age 16

Result: Rank-rank relationship between parent percentile rank and child percentile rank is almost perfectly linear nationally; estimated national rank-rank slope ~0.341 (a 10 percentile increase in parent rank -> 3.41 percentile increase in child rank)

Claim / Methodological finding: The canonical log-log intergenerational income elasticity (IGE) is unstable in these data because log-log relation is nonlinear and treatment of zero/very small incomes matters; rank-rank specification is more robust for comparisons

Result: Large geographic variation in mobility across commuting zones (CZs): relative mobility (rank-rank slope) and absolute upward mobility (expected child rank at parent p=25) vary widely; examples: probability of rising from bottom quintile to top quintile ranges from ~4.4% (Charlotte) to 12.9% (San Jose); r25 ranges ~35.8 (Charlotte) to 46.2 (Salt Lake City) among largest CZs

Evidence: Spatial rank-rank relationships are approximately linear within CZs and allow summary by slope (relative mobility) and intercept (absolute outcomes); absolute and relative mobility are highly correlated across CZs (unweighted corr ~ -0.68)

Result: Outcomes that reflect pathways (college attendance, college quality, teenage birth) are strongly and linearly correlated with parent rank nationally and exhibit similar geographic variation to income mobility, suggesting drivers operate while children are growing up

Claim / Correlational evidence: Five CZ-level factors are strongly correlated with lower upward mobility: (i) greater residential segregation (especially segregation of poverty), (ii) greater income inequality among the bottom 99% (higher Gini excluding top 1%), (iii) lower K–12 school quality (income-adjusted test scores and dropouts), (iv) lower social capital, and (v) weaker family structure (higher share of single parents)

Evidence: Correlations and multivariable regressions — segregation, bottom-99% inequality, income-adjusted school outcomes, social capital index, and fraction single parents each explain substantial cross-CZ variation; together these proxies explain large share of variation and remain significant with state fixed effects

Claim: Relationship between race and mobility is largely place-level: CZs with larger African American populations have lower mobility for both black and white residents; race shares lose significance once community-level family structure and other factors are controlled

Limitation: These are descriptive, cross-sectional correlations; variables are endogenous and cannot be interpreted causally here; authors note follow-up causal analyses show part of spatial variation is causal (Chetty & Hendren 2014)

Robustness / Evidence: Estimates robust to many checks — measurement years, sample cohorts, life-cycle (child income stabilizes by age ~30), attenuation (using 5-year parent income averages), alternative income definitions, cost-of-living adjustments, growth adjustments, and alternative mobility metrics

Conclusion: Geography matters substantially for intergenerational mobility; local characteristics explain a large share of cross-area differences, suggesting place-based policy interventions could matter although causal identification is needed
